captures.author: @ModernDad
captures.text:
My wife calls me, panicked. 

The call is from her number, and her voice is unmistakable- that‚Äôs my wife. 

‚ÄòBabe, our son is hurt. He got in a bike wreck. I‚Äôm at the emergency room but they won‚Äôt take our insurance and I need cash to get him help. Please send me 3000 dollars as soon as you can, he‚Äôs really not doing well.‚Äô 

Me- ‚ÄòWow, that‚Äôs scary. Tell me our passphrase and then I‚Äôll send the money.‚Äô 

Her (it) - ‚ÄòWhat? What passphrase? This is your wife, our son is hurt. Send the money now!!‚Äô 

Me- ‚ÄòI‚Äôll call you back. I don‚Äôt believe that this is my wife. If it is, I‚Äôm sorry, but we discussed this.‚Äô 

The number? Spoofed. Easy to do and there‚Äôs no way to tell if a phone number is being spoofed aside from hanging up and calling back to confirm. 

The voice? AI generated. Easily done. A few seconds of audio is all it takes to create a realistic audio deepfake.

What can you do? 

1) Create a family safe word or passphrase. Ours is definitely not ‚ÄòKeep Going‚Äô although we considered it. Discuss the passphrase far away from phones or any recording device. This is as analog as possible. Don‚Äôt forget that the trigger for the passphrase is just as important as the phrase itself. So instead of asking ‚Äòwhat‚Äôs the safe word?‚Äô have a separate triggering question. For example, you could say ‚ÄòI‚Äôm eating banana cream pie‚Äô and this would trigger your spouse to respond ‚Äòpurple velvet pillows‚Äô if that‚Äôs the safe word. 

Make it fun, silly, and easy to remember. And DON‚ÄôT WRITE IT DOWN. 

2) Cognitive security is an essential skill in 2026. Assume every image and video you see online is fake until proven otherwise. Expect scams and spammers, and be pleasantly surprised when it‚Äôs not. 

3) Figure out a backup communication option with people who you absolutely need to be able to reach. Don‚Äôt just rely on a phone number for communication. Have redundant, ideally encrypted methods of communication with family. 

What did I miss? I think (hope) Nikita is wrong on the timeframe- agentic bots like Claude bot are impressive but not quite ready to flood the phone lines in just 90 days. But I think it‚Äôs going to be a huge problem by the end of the year. I already get dozens of increasingly realistic spam calls and texts daily- it‚Äôs only going to get more annoying. Have a plan to keep your family and your finances safe!

This is the most honest "we built a tool" post I've read in months.

Most AI product stories skip straight to the demo. This one starts with "reality punched me in the face on Day 1" and walks through every actual failure before the solution.

The context rot problem alone is worth reading for. Every team running ai agents internally is hitting this exact wall and pretending they aren't. @Team9_ai

captures.author: @TheMindScourge
captures.text:
In an age of strong AI, you need to be thinking like an aristocrat. 

Aristocrats don‚Äôt think about jobs. They don‚Äôt go to university to acquire ‚Äúskills‚Äù but to network and gain polish. They respect risk-taking but disparage grindset. They tend to be histrionic, inconsistent, and difficult to manage. They respect risk-taking and deal-making. 

This is a Lindy personality type that was selected against during the 20th century but will thrive under conditions of strong AI

captures.author: @signulll
captures.text:
one of my favorite ways to generate think about ai:

- pick a specific persona.
- then work backwards & ask what would it take for this one person to scale themselves 100x? purely through leverage, not necessarily by working harder.

in many ways ai startups are basically ‚Äúhuman multiplier‚Äù factories. essentially you're picking a human & turning them into a company.
